title: Ventura County Sheriff’s Sgt. Among 7 Killed in Flash Floods in Zion National Park
content:
A veteran of the Ventura County Sheriff’s Office was one of the seven people killed when flash floods hit Zion National Park in Utah earlier this week. 
 
Sgt. Robert “Steve” Arthur is seen in an image provided by the Ventura County Sheriff’s Office. 
 
Sgt. Robert “Steve” Arthur, of Camarillo, was walking with his wife Linda Arthur when a series of flash floods struck the region Monday, according to a news release from the Ventura County Sheriff’s Office. 
 
Steve Arthur’s body was positively identified two days later as one of the victims of the flooding, the Sheriff’s Office stated. Recovery efforts were still underway for Linda Arthur. 
 
Steve Arthur, a 21-year veteran of the Sheriff’s Office, was assigned to the Camarillo Police Department as the Traffic Supervisor, according to the news release. 
 
“Steve was known for his tireless efforts working with local youth both on and off duty and possessed a huge compassion for humanity,” the news release read. 
 
Arthur was survived by three adult children and seven grandchildren, according to the Sheriff’s Office. 
 
The bodies of five others who were killed when the flash floods hit Keyhole Canyon have been recovered, according to The Salt Lake Tribune . 
 
Park officials have not released the names of the victims, according to the newspaper.
